block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

Iraqi Minister Pressured By U.S. for War Progress The top American military commander for the Middle East warned Iraq's prime minister in a closed door conversation that the Iraqi government needed to make tangible political progress by next month to counter the growing opposition to the war in Congress. A1

The Iraqi Parliament approved a resolution that would force the resignation of the speaker, Mahmoud Mashadani. The vote underscored the widespread discontent with Mr. Mashadani, a Sunni Arab politician who has done little to build consensus among Iraq's political blocs. A8

In Egypt, Abundant Fatwas Fatwa, or Islamic religious edicts, have become a cause for controversy in Egypt. The complaint has been the subject of recent conferences as government-appointed arbiters of Islamic standards say the fatwa free-for-all has led to the promotion of extremism and intolerance. A1

U.N. Warning to U.S. and Iran The director general of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency warned Tehran and Washington for the first time that their stalemate over Iran's nuclear activities was turning into a confrontation that ''urgently needs to be defused.'' A8

Palestinian Infighting Rages The worst factional fighting in nearly a month raged among Palestinians, with gunmen reportedly firing at the prime minister's home and office. Violence elsewhere in Gaza left at least nine people dead. A12

Nairobi Hit by Blast An explosion rocked Nairobi, killing one person and wounding 31 others. Witnesses said three men carrying a small bomb tried to squeeze onto a crowded bus, but when they were pushed off by other passengers, the bomb exploded. A12

In Kabul, Bomb Like Ones in Iraq Afghan security forces found a bomb of the type used in Iraq in Kabul last month, the first time such a device has been discovered in the capital. The bomb was primed to hit a convoy of Afghan officials or international forces, the official said. A8
NATIONAL A13-21

Detention of 'Combatants' In U.S. Rejected by Court The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be ''enemy combatants'' and have the military hold them indefinitely, a stinging rejection of the Bush administration's central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism.
A1

Vote Against Gonzales Blocked Senate Republicans blocked a symbolic no confidence vote against Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, dismissing the measure as an irrelevant gesture, though Democrats had hoped it might intensify pressure on Mr. Gonzales to resign. A1

Dog Breeders Using DNA Tests As dog breeders apply scientific precision to their art, they find that the quest for genetic perfection comes with unforeseen consequences. And the lessons of intervening in the nature of dogs may ultimately bear as much on humans as on their best friends.
A1
Senate Debates Energy Bill With gasoline prices hovering near all-time highs, the Senate began debating a sprawling energy bill that has already kicked off an epic lobbying war by huge industries.

Man in Sex Case Ordered Freed A judge ordered the release of a man who is serving a widely criticized 10-year prison sentence without parole for having consensual oral sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party four years ago. But Georgia's attorney general, Thurbert E. Baker, said he was appealing the order.

Guards Accused of Smuggling Three members of the Texas National Guard helping patrol the Mexican border have been charged with human smuggling after federal agents found one of the soldiers in uniform driving a van crammed with 24 illegal immigrants north of Laredo.

Disparity in Law to Be Reviewed The Supreme Court, expanding its review of federal criminal sentencing, agreed to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder.
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Police Cite Gang Activity In Rash of Parade Arrests The New York police disclosed that 208 people were arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday -- far more than in previous years -- after reports that members of the Latin Kings gang planned to join the parade. But several of those arrested said they had simply been swept up with the crowd and denied having any gang associations. B1

Silver Criticizes Traffic Plan Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, in his strongest language yet against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to charge people who drive into the most congested parts of Manhattan, suggested that many of the environmental goals the mayor has outlined could be met without congestion pricing. B1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-8

Science Flirts With Invisibility Increasingly, physicists are constructing materials that bend light the ''wrong'' way, an optical trick that could lead to sharper-than-ever lenses or maybe even make objects disappear. F1

Findings in Animal Migration The first aerial survey of southern Sudan in 25 years has revealed vast migrating herds, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, that have managed to survive 25 years of civil war, the Wildlife Conservation Society and Southern Sudan will announce at a news conference. F1
Cancer Drug's Limitations Studies show that the breast cancer drug Herceptin is given only to the 20 percent of breast cancer patients whose tumors have a particular genetic characteristic. F5
Health & Fitness F5
OBITUARIES B7
Lee Nagrin A noted Off Broadway performance artist, director and charter member of Meredith Monk's theater company, she was 78. B7
BUSINESS DAY C1-16

Counseling on Mortgages With a number of homeowners running into problems paying off their mortgages, Illinois came up with a new mandatory state program to counsel borrowers on their mortgages. But the Illinois approach raises questions about how far regulators can go into trying to safeguard consumers.
A1

Editorials: A ruling for justice; misdirected studies on Avandia; still dying in Congo; the discoverer's DNA.
Columns: David Brooks and Bob Herbert.
